slides.title: Introduction to Global Warming
slides.content: Global warming refers to the long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period (between 1850 and 1900) due to human activities, primarily fossil fuel burning, which increases heat-trapping greenhouse gas levels in Earth's atmosphere.
slides.notes: Define global warming clearly. Emphasize the role of human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels. Note the long-term trend.

elements.description: Arrow pointing upwards, representing rising temperatures.

slides.title: Causes of Global Warming
slides.content:
The primary cause is the increase in greenhouse gases:
*   Carbon Dioxide (CO2)
*   Methane (CH4)
*   Nitrous Oxide (N2O)

These gases trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to a gradual warming of the planet.
slides.notes: Explain the greenhouse effect in simple terms. List the major greenhouse gases and their sources.  Mention deforestation as a contributing factor.

elements.description: Drawing of the greenhouse effect, showing sunlight entering and heat being trapped.

slides.title: Evidence of Global Warming
slides.content:
Observable evidence includes:
*   Rising Global Temperatures
*   Melting Glaciers and Ice Sheets
*   Rising Sea Levels
*   Changes in Precipitation Patterns
*   More Frequent Extreme Weather Events
slides.notes: Present concrete evidence of global warming. Show data on temperature increases, ice melt, and sea level rise.  Give examples of extreme weather events linked to climate change.

elements.description: Chart showing global temperature increase over time.

slides.title: Impacts on the Environment
slides.content:
*   Loss of Biodiversity
*   Ocean Acidification
*   Coral Reef Bleaching
*   Changes in Ecosystems
*   Increased Wildfires
slides.notes: Discuss the devastating effects of global warming on the environment. Highlight the vulnerability of ecosystems and species.

elements.description: Images of dying coral reefs and endangered species.

slides.title: Impacts on Human Society
slides.content:
*   Food Security Issues
*   Water Scarcity
*   Increased Displacement and Migration
*   Health Problems (heatstroke, respiratory illnesses)
*   Economic Losses
slides.notes: Explain how global warming affects human societies, particularly vulnerable populations. Discuss the social, economic, and health consequences.

elements.description: Image depicting drought-stricken land and displaced people.

slides.title: Mitigation Strategies
slides.content:
*   Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions
*   Transitioning to Renewable Energy Sources (solar, wind, hydro)
*   Improving Energy Efficiency
*   Reforestation and Afforestation
*   Carbon Capture and Storage
slides.notes: Describe actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down global warming.  Focus on renewable energy, energy efficiency, and carbon sequestration.

slides.title: Adaptation Strategies
slides.content:
*   Developing Drought-Resistant Crops
*   Building Flood Defenses
*   Improving Water Management
*   Relocating Communities at Risk
*   Strengthening Public Health Systems
slides.notes: Discuss strategies to cope with the unavoidable impacts of climate change. Emphasize the importance of adaptation for vulnerable communities.

elements.description: Image of a flood barrier or drought-resistant crops.

slides.title: Call to Action: What Can You Do?
slides.content:
*   Reduce Your Carbon Footprint
*   Support Sustainable Businesses
*   Advocate for Climate Action
*   Educate Others
*   Make Informed Choices
slides.notes: Inspire the audience to take action. Provide practical tips and encourage them to become climate advocates.

elements.description: Image of people working together to protect the environment.
